introduction: The Consumer Protection Act aims to protect consumers from exploitation and unfair business practices.
Businesses have a legal responsibility to protect/promote the rights of consumers.
Businesses that comply with the CPA are able to reduce heavy penalties.

points: Promotes fair/accessible and sustainable places for people to sell their products.
Establishes national standards to protect consumers regardless of economic status.
Provides guidelines for better consumer information.

positives: Prevents larger businesses from undermining smaller ones.
Builds good image if they do not violate consumer rights.
negatives: Confidential business information may become available to competitors.
Penalties for non-compliance may be very high.
Staff training/legal experts increase operational costs.

rights: Right to choose (Shop around, return unsafe goods).

Right to disclosure and information (Plain language contracts, correct labelling).
Right to fair and responsible marketing.
Right to equality in the consumer market.

points: Display business name on all documents.

conclusion: The CPA requires both businesses and consumers to act responsibly.
